I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the study and 
the promotion of the implementation of market conduct supervision in the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) that is integrated within the framework for financial consumer protection. The TA will 
expand upon the TA to the PRC for Promotion of a Legal Framework for Financial Consumer 
Protection, completed in September 2015 that established a framework for financial consumer 
protection and supported cooperation among the various government stakeholders. 1  
 
2.  The TA is listed in the 2017–2019 country operations business plan for the PRC.2 
Following a fact-finding mission in May 2017, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the 
government reached an understanding on the objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, 
costs, and terms of reference for the TA.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The impacts of global financial crisis in 2008 highlighted the need for more effective 
financial consumer protection measures as consumers face more sophisticated and complex 
financial  markets,  products  and  services.  New  product  developments,  financial  service 
innovations, and technological advances including the rise of financial technology (FinTech) has 
increased dramatically and raised the need to improve the capacity and protection of financial 
consumers in using and accessing finance.4 Building and maintaining consumer confidence and 
trust in financial markets promotes efficiency and stability and helps to create positive outcomes 
for both financial institutions and their customers. Consumers need knowledge, information, and 
security  to  enable  them  to  fully  participate  in  financial  markets  and  make  sound  choices. 
Additionally, there needs to be a strong framework of supervision over the providers of financial 
products and services to consumers through the imposition of market conduct supervision.5  
 
4.  There are four approaches to financial regulation depending on the degree of integration 
of market conduct supervision and financial consumer protection with prudential supervision. 
Under one supervision model, consumer protection and market conduct, including review of 
business practices, are carried out by separate regulatory agencies from those responsible for 
prudential regulation.6 While no two jurisdictions regulate financial institutions and market conduct 
in the same manner, the models adopted worldwide can be divided into four categories: (i) the 
institutional approach, (ii) the functional approach, (iii) the integrated approach, and (iv) the “Twin 
                                                
1  ADB. 2013.  Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Promotion of a Legal Framework for Financial 
Consumer Protection. Manila. 
2   ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan, People's Republic of China, 2017–2019. Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the ADB's website on 12 August 2017. 
4   Financial Technology or “FinTech” can be described as the industry of generally non-bank institutions that uses new 
technologies such as the internet, artificial intelligence, mobile services, and other innovations to provide financial 
services directly to consumers more rapidly and in competition with the delivery channels of financial products and 
services by traditional financial institutions such as banks. 
5  Market conduct supervision is an element of financial consumer protection that focused on the behavior of financial 
institutions to ensure they do not perform distortive or abusive practices and that appropriate information disclosure 
is provided to consumers when they utilize financial services.  
6   Prudential regulation refers to both macro-prudential and micro-prudential supervision. Macro-prudential supervision 
refers to the oversight of financial stability and systemic financial system concerns while micro-prudential supervision 
refers to the direct oversight of the practices of banks and financial institutions.

2 
Peaks” approach.7 An evolving practice structure for this oversight is the so called “Twin Peaks” 
approach of financial regulation.8 No pure example of any approach exists. The specific way in 
which  regulation  and  supervision  has  been  structured  in  each  country  reflects  the  unique 
individual  history,  politics,  culture,  financial  sector  size,  economic  development,  and  local 
structures.  The  PRC  is  currently  following  the  institutional  approach  in  that  the  regulatory 
authorities  have  been  established  along  institutional  or  sector‐based  lines  and  separate 
authorities have been established to regulate the banking, insurance, and securities sectors.9 
Within this context, each of the PRC’s financial regulators have also established their own 
individual units for financial consumer protection. The China Securities Regulatory Commission 
created one in December 2011, and China Insurance Regulatory Commission in November 2011, 
while the China Banking Regulatory Commission in 2012. The People’s Bank of China (PBC) 
created the Financial Consumer Protection Bureau (FCPB) in June 2012. Each entity is generally 
responsible for supervision of financial consumer protection within its own mandate.  
 
5.  As the PRC’s financial system has become more complex and integrated, the need for 
structural reform has grown particularly with regards to financial consumer protection and market 
conduct. A reform agenda is outlined in the 13th Five-year Plan for the Development and Reform 
of  the  Financial  Industry.10 Regarding  consumers,  the  agenda  supports  financial-inclusion 
programs, supporting use of technological innovation, supporting lending in rural areas and to 
small and micro enterprises, and improved consumer and investor protection through stronger 
supervision and greater disclosure. The financial sector has become increasingly integrated and 
the lines between traditional banking, securities, and insurance have become blurred. Further, 
non-traditional institutions have become successful in offering financial products and services and 
these offerings are often under-regulated. The institutional approach in the PRC is facing the need 
to accommodate these financial sector changes. There is greater need to protect financial 
consumers  by  further  clarifying  the  relationship  between  market  conduct  supervision  and 
prudential supervision.  
 
6.  There is a strong link between protecting financial consumers from abusive products and 
practices,  and  safety  and  soundness  of  financial  system. Consumer  confidence  and  trust 
promotes financial stability, growth, efficiency, and innovation in the financial system over the long 
term. It is within this context that the PBC has decided to strengthen market conduct supervision 
within their financial consumer protection framework. The need exists to ensure consumers are 
treated fairly when seeking and using financial products and services. Improved protection 
                                                
7  The institutional approach is a legal-entity-driven approach. The firm’s legal status essentially determines which 
regulator is tasked with overseeing its activity both from a safety and soundness and a business conduct perspective.  
Oversight in the functional approach is determined by the business that is being transacted by each entity without 
regard to its legal status. In the integrated approach, there is a single regulator that conducts both safety and 
soundness oversight and conduct-of-business regulation for all the sectors of the financial services industry. The 
prior UK Financial Services Authority was the prime example of this model.  The Twin Peaks approach is based on 
the principle of regulation by objective and refers to a separation of regulatory functions between two regulators: one 
that performs the safety and soundness supervision function and the other that focuses on conduct-of-business 
regulation including financial consumer protection.  
8   The Twin Peaks approach was adopted in Australia in 1998 with the creation of the Australian Prudential Regulatory 
Authority that regulates banks, building societies and credit unions, life and general insurance and reinsurance 
companies, friendly societies and superannuation funds, investment banks and finance companies. The Australian 
Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) and the Australian Securities Exchange regulate market conduct 
and ASIC also has responsibility for market integrity and consumer protection. 
9  The China Banking Regulatory Commission supervises banks; the China Insurance Regulatory Commission 
supervises the insurance industry; and the China Securities Regulatory Commission supervises securities markets 
along with other industry groups. 
10  The 13th Five-Year Plan for Economic and Social Development of the People’s Republic of China (2016–2020) 
Beijing. http://en.ndrc.gov.cn/policyrelease/201612/P020161207645766966662.pdf

3 
ultimately benefits overall financial market development and stability also being a core mandate 
function of the PBC. The method chosen and implemented must address three core concerns: (i) 
insufficient information that limits the ability of consumers to make sound decisions on financial 
products and services; (ii) the risk of abusive practices due to limited competition and a lack of 
transparency; and (iii) barriers to the development of appropriate financial products and services 
that can properly serve and fulfill the needs of the poor, the rural population, and small businesses.  
 
B.  Proposed Solutions 
 
7.  It is necessary in the PRC to further strengthen the approach to consumer protection and 
more effectively incorporate market conduct supervision in financial services to create a more 
resilient and stable financial system. The PBC is planning to evaluate the various methods for 
implementing market conduct supervision and proposing a new path for its integration within the 
role of the PBC and financial consumer protection. At this stage, the TA will assist the PBC to 
evaluate the current domestic situation and concerns, seek the alternatives with their benefits and 
likelihood for a best fit with local circumstances, and propose a roadmap that can be followed for 
implementation. Solutions will propose adoption of methods in line with international financial and 
codes of practices that solidify commitments of the PRC as a member of the G-2011 and are 
consistent with recommendations in the 2011 Financial System Stability Assessment Report12 
prepared by the IMF and those in the 2015 Peer Review of China prepared by the Financial 
Stability Board.13 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: Financial system regulatory reform and 
accountability deepened.14 TA will have the following outcome: financial consumer protection 
strengthened.15 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  
9.  Output 1: Framework on market conduct supervision in financial services prepared. 
The output will seek a framework to enhance oversight of market conduct within the role of the 
PBC and supporting the adoption of international financial codes of practices. This output will 
support: (i) preparation of at least five detailed studies and reports that clarify the relationship 
between market conduct oversight and integration with financial consumer protection consistent 
with the role and mandate of the PBC, (ii) completion of a roadmap that can be used as a guide 
for the adoption and implementation of the selected best-fit model for market conduct supervision, 
and (iii) recommendations from reports and roadmap acknowledged by the PBC’s FCPB and 
submitted to the Governor to support preparation of policy proposals on financial consumer 
protection and a mechanism for market conduct supervision. A study tour will also be sponsored 
for key management and staff from the PBC’s FCPB to ADB member countries that have adopted 
                                                
11 Group of Twenty is an international forum for the governments and central banks of Argentina, Australia, Brazil, 
Canada, PRC, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Russia, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Republic 
of Korea, Turkey, United Kingdom, United States, and the European Union.  
12 IMF. 2011.  People’s Republic of China: Financial System Stability Assessment. Washington D.C. 
13 Financial Stability Board. 2015. Peer Review of China, Review Report. Basel 
14 Defined by the TA. 
15  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
the model determined to be the best fit in the PRC’s circumstances to provide a first-hand view of 
the practical issues faced with adopting such a model. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Understanding  of  market  conduct  supervision  by  government  and 
financial sector stakeholders enhanced. The output will see market conduct supervision in the 
PRC promoted. This output will support: (i) at least 25 government officials (at least 5 female) 
through attendance at a national workshop, will have improved knowledge and understanding of 
market conduct supervision and help solidify plans for the implementation of market conduct 
supervision, (ii) at least 30 PBC staff and management who attend training sessions will report 
improved understanding of market conduct supervision, and (iii) at least 30 participants  (at least 
8 female) who attend an international conference will report increased understanding of market 
conduct supervision within the financial consumer protection mechanism and commitment to 
promote its integration. The conference will highlight best cases in terms of observance of 
international financial standards related to market conduct, and supporting the role of cross-
border supervisory cooperation and exchange of information. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $400,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
12.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff travel and 
venues for workshops, staff training and conferences, meeting space, access to needed material, 
printing and distribution of project material, assistance in coordinating meetings, and other in-kind 
contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB 
will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; support the implementing agency to organize 
workshops; and identify and provide staff to act as resource persons as needed.  An advance 
payment facility will be used for training, seminar, and conference administration by the executing 
agency. 
 
14.  The TA will be monitored and evaluated based on the implementation of activities and 
satisfactory delivery of outputs as per the agreed timeline and budget. To support monitoring and 
evaluation, consultants will submit inception and interim reports. TA review missions will be used 
to  aid  in  monitoring  progress,  as  well  as  regular  communication  with  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies and consultants. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects   Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  November 2017 – March 2019 
Executing agency  The People’s Bank of China 
Implementing agency  Financial Consumer Protection Bureau of the People’s Bank of 
China 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB

to time). 
Source: Asian Development Bank.  
 
15.  Consulting services. The consultants as well as resource persons will be engaged by 
ADB in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time).16 
Consultants will have expertise in market conduct and financial consumer protection supervision. 
Consultants will be recruited individually using output-based, lump sum contracts with a provision 
for fixed out-of-pocket expenditures.17 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People's Republic of China for Establishing a Market Conduct Supervision 
Mechanism for Financial Consumer Protection and hereby reports this action to the Board.  
 
 
 
                                                
16  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
17 In line with MTR Action Plan Nos. 2.9.2. and 2.10.2.

Note: The technical assistance is estimated to cost $430,000, of which contributions from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) are presented in the table. The government's counterpart support is in the form of counterpart staff and 
management time, office space, full access to all materials needed, and other in-kind contributions. The value of 
government contribution is estimated to account for 7% of the total technical assistance (TA) cost. 
a  Financed by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
b  Includes translation and interpretation of key documents and reports and of key meetings. This may include the costs 
for externally contracted translators or interpreters or the possibility to reimburse the People’s Bank of China for their 
internal costs for translation and interpretation. 
c   Includes the costs of arrangement of venues, and translation and interpretation for workshops and conferences, 
honoraria and travel costs for resource persons, and international and national expert speakers at inception meetings, 
coordination workshops, and a final international conference. Specific budget and arrangements are subject to prior 
approval by ADB. In the exceptional case where an ADB staff member acts as a resource person, travel costs will 
be charged to the TA with prior agreement with the implementing agency.   
d  To be held in ADB eligible member countries with advanced financial consumer protection and market conduct 
supervision frameworks. Initially, it is estimated that the study tour will be held in the United Kingdom or the United 
States. 
e  May include support costs, and the cost of disseminating and translating the final report.
